<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">Under the Bank Secrecy Act (&#8220;BSA&#8221;), a financial institution is required to have systems in place to detect certain transactions, based on the size and nature of the transactions.&#160;&#160;Financial institutions are generally required to report to the United States Treasury cash transactions involving more than $10,000.&#160;&#160;In addition, financial institutions are required to file suspicious activity reports for transactions that involve more than $5,000 and that the financial institution knows, suspects, or has reason to suspect involve illegal funds, are designed to evade the requirements of the BSA, or have no lawful purpose.&#160;&#160;The USA PATRIOT Act of 2001 (the &#8220;PATRIOT Act&#8221;), which amended the BSA, contains anti-money laundering and financial-transparency laws, as well as enhanced information collection tools and enforcement mechanisms for the U.S. government.&#160;&#160;PATRIOT Act provisions include the following:&#160;&#160;standards for verifying customer identification when opening accounts; rules to promote cooperation among financial institutions, regulators and law enforcement agencies; and due diligence requirements for financial institutions that administer, maintain or manage certain bank accounts.&#160;&#160;The Bank is subject to BSA and PATRIOT Act requirements.&#160;&#160;Bank regulators carefully review an institution&#8217;s compliance with these requirements when examining an institution and consider the institution&#8217;s compliance when evaluating an application submitted by an institution.&#160;&#160;Bank regulators may require an institution to take various actions to ensure that it is meeting the requirements of these acts.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Brokered Deposits</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">Well-capitalized institutions are not subject to limitations on brokered deposits.&#160;&#160;An adequately capitalized institution is able to accept, renew or roll over brokered deposits only with a waiver from the FDIC and is subject to certain restrictions on the yield paid on such deposits.&#160;&#160;Undercapitalized institutions are not permitted to accept, renew or roll over brokered deposits.&#160;&#160;Under the current Order, the Bank may not accept brokered deposits without the prior written consent of the FDIC and the IDFPR.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Acquisition and Ownership of Common Stock May&#160;Be Restricted by Bank Regulators</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">Any person or group that purchases 10 percent or more of the Company&#8217;s common stock, or hereafter acquires additional securities such that its interest in the Company exceeds 10 percent, may be required to obtain approval of the Federal Reserve pursuant to the Change in Bank Control Act and the FDIA as well as the approval of the IDFPR.&#160;&#160;Further, any corporation, partnership, trust or organized group that acquires a controlling interest in the Company may have to obtain approval of the Federal Reserve to become a bank holding company and thereafter be subject to regulation as such.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Consumer Laws</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">In addition to the CRA, other federal and state laws regulate various lending and consumer aspects of the banking business.&#160;&#160;These laws include the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, the Fair Housing Act, Truth in Lending Act, the Truth in Savings Act, the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act and the Electronic Funds Transfer Act.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">2008 Emergency Economic Stabilization Act</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">On October&#160;3, 2008, the U.S. Congress enacted the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (&#8220;EESA&#8221;) in response to the financial turmoil in the banking industry.&#160;&#160;EESA authorized the Secretary of the U.S. Department of the Treasury to purchase up to $700 billion in troubled assets from qualifying financial institutions pursuant to the Troubled Asset Relief Program (&#8220;TARP&#8221;).&#160;&#160;On October&#160;14, 2008, the </font></div>

<div><br>
</div>

<div>
<div id="PGBRK" style="TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; WIDTH: 100%; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt">
<div id="FTR">
<div id="GLFTR" style="WIDTH: 100%" align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 8pt">&#160; </font></div>
</div>

<div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always; WIDTH: 100%">
<div style="TEXT-ALIGN: center; WIDTH: 100%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">24</font></div>

<div style="TEXT-ALIGN: center; WIDTH: 100%">
<hr style="COLOR: black" noshade size="2">
</div>
</div>

<div id="HDR">
<div id="GLHDR" style="WIDTH: 100%" align="left"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 8pt"><a href="#TOC">Table of Contents</a></font></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div><br>
</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">U.S. Department of the Treasury (&#8220;US Treasury&#8221;), pursuant to its authority under EESA, announced the Capital Purchase Program (&#8220;CPP&#8221;).&#160;&#160;Pursuant to the CPP, qualifying small bank financial institutions, with assets totaling less than $500 million, were permitted to issue senior preferred stock to the US Treasury in an amount not less than 1 percent of the institution&#8217;s risk-weighted assets and not more than 5 percent of the institution&#8217;s risk-weighted assets.&#160;&#160;Financial institutions participating in the CPP must agree and comply with certain restrictions, including restrictions on dividends, stock redemptions, stock repurchases and executive compensation.&#160;&#160;Pursuant to the CPP, the US Treasury may unilaterally amend any provision of the CPP to comply with changes in applicable federal statutes.&#160;&#160;Neither the Company nor the Bank is participating in the CPP.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">FDIC Temporary Liquidity Guarantee Program</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">In October&#160;2008, the FDIC announced the Temporary Liquidity Guarantee Program (&#8220;TLGP&#8221;) to strengthen confidence and encourage liquidity in the banking system.&#160;&#160;The program consists of two components:&#160;&#160;the Transaction Account Guarantee Program (&#8220;TAGP&#8221;) and the Debt Guarantee Program (&#8220;DGP&#8221;).</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline">Transaction Account Guarantee Program</font>.&#160;&#160;Pursuant to the TAGP, the FDIC will fully insure, without limit, qualifying transaction accounts held at qualifying depository institutions through December&#160;31, 2010 (extended from December&#160;31, 2009 provided the institution did not previously opt out of the TAGP).&#160;&#160;Qualifying transaction accounts include non-interest-bearing transaction accounts, Interest on Lawyers Trust Accounts (IOLTAs) and NOW accounts with interest rates less than 0.5 percent.&#160;&#160;The FDIC assessed a fee equal to 10 basis points on transaction account deposit balances in excess of the $250,000 insured limit.&#160;&#160;During the six-month extension period in 2010, the fee assessment increased to 15 basis points, 20 basis points or 25 basis points, based on an institution&#8217;s risk category.&#160;&#160;On April&#160;13, 2010, the board of directors of the FDIC approved an interim rule that would extend the TAGP until December&#160;31, 2010, with further extensions until December&#160;31, 2011 possible without further rulemaking.&#160;&#160;The interim rule, if approved, would also alter the reporting requirements required under the TAGP and alter the requirements for the inclusion of NOW accounts in the TAGP.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline">Debt Guarantee Program</font>.&#160;&#160;Pursuant to the DGP, eligible entities were permitted to issue FDIC-guaranteed senior unsecured debt up to 125 percent of the entity&#8217;s senior unsecured debt outstanding as of September&#160;30, 2008.&#160;&#160;The Company did not issue any guaranteed debt under the DGP.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Dodd-Frank Act</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act was signed into law on July&#160;21, 2010.&#160;&#160;This legislation may have an adverse impact on the Company&#8217;s financial results upon full implementation.&#160;&#160;Among other impacts, this legislation establishes a Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, changes the base for deposit insurance assessments, introduces regulatory rate-setting for interchange fees charged to merchants for debit card transactions, and excludes certain instruments currently included in determining the Tier 1 regulatory capital ratio.&#160;&#160;The capital instrument exclusion will be phased in over a three-year period beginning in 2013.&#160;&#160;Most of the legislation&#8217;s other provisions require rulemaking by various regulatory agencies.&#160;&#160;The Company cannot currently quantify the future impact of this legislation and the related future rulemaking on its business, financial condition or results of operations.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Future Regulatory Uncertainty</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">Because federal regulation of financial institutions changes regularly and is the subject of constant legislative debate regarding issues such as the evolving structure of financial institutions and the evolving competitive relationship among financial institutions and other, similar service providers such as</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div><br>
</div>

<div>
<div id="PGBRK" style="TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; WIDTH: 100%; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt">
<div id="FTR">
<div id="GLFTR" style="WIDTH: 100%" align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 8pt">&#160; </font></div>
</div>

<div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always; WIDTH: 100%">
<div style="TEXT-ALIGN: center; WIDTH: 100%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">25</font></div>

<div style="TEXT-ALIGN: center; WIDTH: 100%">
<hr style="COLOR: black" noshade size="2">
</div>
</div>

<div id="HDR">
<div id="GLHDR" style="WIDTH: 100%" align="left"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 8pt"><a href="#TOC">Table of Contents</a></font></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div><br>
</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">securities firms and insurance companies, we cannot predict how federal regulation of financial institutions may change in the future.&#160;&#160;Due to the recent financial and real estate market turmoil, the US Government has implemented numerous programs designed to stabilize the financial markets and economy.&#160;&#160;Although we cannot predict what new policies or programs will impact the Company or the Bank, we fully expect that the financial institution industry will remain heavily regulated and that additional laws or regulations will likely be adopted that will impact the operations of the Company and the Bank.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Concentrations in Commercial Real Estate Lending</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">In December&#160;2006, the OCC, together with the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and the Federal Insurance Corporation (the &#8220;Agencies&#8221;), issued guidance entitled &#8220;Concentrations in Commercial Real Estate Lending, Sound Risk Management Practices&#8221; (the &#8220;Guidance&#8221;).&#160;&#160;The Guidance indicates it is intended to &#8220;reinforce and enhance the Agencies&#8217; existing regulations and guidelines for real estate lending&#8221; and, to &#8220;remind institutions that strong risk management practices and appropriate levels of capital are important elements of a sound Commercial Real Estate (&#8220;CRE&#8221;) lending program, particularly when an institution has a concentration in CRE loans.&#8221;&#160;&#160;Importantly, the Guidance states that it, &#8220;...does not establish specific CRE lending limits; rather, it promotes sound risk management practices and appropriate levels of capital that will enable institutions to continue to pursue CRE lending in a safe and sound manner.&#8221;</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">While the Guidance states that it, &#8220;...does not define a CRE concentration,&#8221; it does outline &#8216;supervisory monitoring criteria&#8217; that, &#8220;...the Agencies will use as high-level indicators to identify institutions potentially exposed to CRE concentration risk.&#8221;&#160;&#160;Those criteria are:&#160;&#160;&#8220;(1)&#160;Total loans for construction, land development, and other land representing 100 percent or more of the institution&#8217;s total capital, or (2)&#160;Total commercial real estate loans representing 300% or more of the institution&#8217;s total capital, and the outstanding balance of the institution&#8217;s commercial real estate portfolio increasing by 50% or more during the prior 36 months.&#8221;</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">As of December&#160;31, 2010, the Bank had balances outstanding for construction, land development, and other land-secured loans totaling $1.8 million, which represented 50% of the Bank&#8217;s total capital.&#160;&#160;The Bank&#8217;s capital is essentially equal to its shareholder equity plus loan loss reserves.&#160;&#160;Also as of December&#160;31, 2010, the Bank had commercial real estate loan balances, including multifamily housing loans, outstanding totaling $26.1 million, which represented 502% of the Bank&#8217;s total capital.&#160;&#160;As a result, the Bank&#8217;s commercial real estate loan ratio was significantly greater than the regulatory criteria as of December&#160;31, 2010.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">The Order issued by the FDIC and IDFPR includes a requirement that the Bank &#8220;adopt, implement and thereafter ensure Bank adherence to&#8221; a revised written commercial real estate (&#8220;CRE&#8221;) concentration management program (the &#8220;Program&#8221;) designed to manage the risk in the Bank&#8217;s CRE portfolio in accordance with regulatory guidelines.&#160;&#160;While Covenant intends to comply with the FDIC and IDFPR&#8217;s request, we will not be able to change the Bank&#8217;s commercial real estate concentration until such time as we originate new loans outside of the commercial real estate sector.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><a name="Item1A">Item 1A</a>.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;Risk Factors.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">There is&#160;<font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">uncertainty</font> about our ability to continue operations.&#160;&#160;<font style="FONT-STYLE: normal; FONT-WEIGHT: normal">In order to successfully operate, we need to stem our loan losses and raise capital in an amount sufficient for us to achieve profitability</font></font>.&#160;&#160;Our existing capital may not be sufficient to absorb our future losses.&#160;&#160;To the extent the Bank&#8217;s loan losses and operating losses exceed its capital, the Bank could be found insolvent.&#160;&#160;Any such event could be expected to result in a loss of all or a substantial portion of the value of the Company&#8217;s outstanding securities, including its common stock.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div><br>
</div>

<div>
<div id="PGBRK" style="TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; WIDTH: 100%; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt">
<div id="FTR">
<div id="GLFTR" style="WIDTH: 100%" align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 8pt">&#160; </font></div>
</div>

<div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always; WIDTH: 100%">
<div style="TEXT-ALIGN: center; WIDTH: 100%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">26</font></div>

<div style="TEXT-ALIGN: center; WIDTH: 100%">
<hr style="COLOR: black" noshade size="2">
</div>
</div>

<div id="HDR">
<div id="GLHDR" style="WIDTH: 100%" align="left"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 8pt"><a href="#TOC">Table of Contents</a></font></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div><br>
</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">Our Board of Directors is pursuing strategic alternatives, including a capital infusion.&#160;&#160;While the Company continues to pursue new capital, it has not received any commitment for a new capital investment, and there can be no assurance that the Company will be able to raise a sufficient amount of new capital in a timely manner, on acceptable terms or at all. If the Company ultimately is unsuccessful in raising a sufficient amount of new capital or, alternatively, executing another strategic initiative, the Bank could be placed into FDIC receivership by its regulators, or the Bank could be acquired by a third party in a transaction in which the Company receives no value for its interest in the Bank.&#160;&#160;We expect that any third party transaction, which would likely involve equity financing, would result in substantial dilution to our current stockholders and could adversely affect the price of our common stock.&#160;&#160;If we are unable to return to profitability and if we are unable to identify and execute a viable strategic alternative, we may be unable to continue as a going concern.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">The Bank has been experiencing performance issues that may be irreversible.&#160;&#160;</font>The Company has incurred cumulative losses since it acquired its sole subsidiary, the Community Bank of Lawndale, now known as Covenant Bank, on March 12, 2008 and expects to incur losses in the future.&#160;&#160;Since March 12, 2008, the Company has incurred losses of approximately $6.2 million through March&#160;31, 2012.&#160;&#160;The Bank has incurred net losses in each of the last ten calendar years.&#160;&#160;There are multiple reasons for these losses, which include losses on loans, goodwill impairment, and high operating expenses.&#160;&#160;The correction of these problems is a difficult task.&#160;&#160;Although the Company has established a new management team, developed a &#8220;turnaround&#8221; plan and implemented a new business strategy and risk management process, there is no assurance that the Company or the Bank will ever be able to operate profitably.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">The Bank may be placed into receivership if it cannot comply with the FDIC and IDFPR Order, or if its condition continues to deteriorate.&#160;&#160;</font>As noted above, the FDIC and IDFPR Order requires the Bank to create and implement a capital plan, including provisions for contingency funding arrangements.&#160;&#160;Pursuant to the Order, among other things, the Bank has agreed to achieve and maintain a Tier 1 capital to total assets ratio of at least 9% and a total risk-based capital ratio of at least 13%.&#160;&#160;As of December 31, 2011, the Bank&#8217;s Tier 1 capital to total assets ratio was 4.43% as compared to 4.81% as of December 31, 2010, and the total risk-based capital ratio was 8.32% as of December 31, 2011 as compared to 9.37% as of December 31, 2010.&#160;&#160;As of December 31, 2011, these ratios were below the targets set by the Consent Order.&#160;&#160;In addition, the condition of the Bank&#8217;s loan portfolio may continue to deteriorate in the current economic environment and thus continue to deplete the Bank&#8217;s capital and other financial resources.&#160;&#160;Should the Bank fail to comply with the Order&#8217;s capital and liquidity funding requirements, or suffer a continued deterioration in its financial condition, the Bank may be subject to being placed into receivership by the FDIC and/or IDFPR, with the FDIC appointed as receiver.&#160;&#160;If these events occur, the Company probably would suffer a complete loss of the value of our ownership interest in the Bank, and we subsequently may be exposed to significant claims by the FDIC and the IDFPR. Any such event could be expected to result in a loss of all or a substantial portion of the value of the Company&#8217;s outstanding securities.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">The Order imposes significant restrictions on our operations, and the cost of compliance, as well as any possible failure to comply, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.</font>&#160;&#160;The Order contains a list of strict requirements, including a capital directive, which requires the Bank to achieve and maintain minimum regulatory capital levels (in excess of the statutory minimums to be classified as well-capitalized) and an obligation to develop a liquidity risk management and contingency funding plan.&#160;&#160;The Order also includes several requirements related to loan administration as well as procedures for managing the Bank&#8217;s growing portfolio of foreclosed real estate assets.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div><br>
</div>

<div>
<div id="PGBRK" style="TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; WIDTH: 100%; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt">
<div id="FTR">
<div id="GLFTR" style="WIDTH: 100%" align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 8pt">&#160; </font></div>
</div>

<div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always; WIDTH: 100%">
<div style="TEXT-ALIGN: center; WIDTH: 100%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">27</font></div>

<div style="TEXT-ALIGN: center; WIDTH: 100%">
<hr style="COLOR: black" noshade size="2">
</div>
</div>

<div id="HDR">
<div id="GLHDR" style="WIDTH: 100%" align="left"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 8pt"><a href="#TOC">Table of Contents</a></font></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div><br>
</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">Any material failure to comply with the provisions of the Order could result in further enforcement actions by the FDIC and/or IDFPR.&#160;&#160;While we are attempting to take such actions as may be necessary to comply with the requirements of the Order, we may be unable to comply fully with its provisions, or our efforts to comply with the Order may have adverse effects on our operations and financial condition.&#160;&#160;There can be no assurance&#160;that&#160;the Company will&#160;be able to raise the amount of capital necessary to&#160;comply with the Order or&#160;to maintain the solvency of the Bank.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Non-performing assets take significant time to resolve and adversely affect the Company&#8217;s results of operations and financial condition, and could result in further losses in the future.</font>&#160;&#160;At December&#160;31, 2010 and 2009, our non-performing loans (which consist of non-accrual loans and loans past due 90 days or more and still-accruing loans) totaled $4.5 million and $1.9 million, or 8.2% and 3.4% of our loan portfolio, respectively.&#160;&#160;At December&#160;31, 2010 and 2009, total non-performing loans plus other real estate owned were $4.8 million and $1.9 million, respectively.&#160;&#160;As of March&#160;31, 2012, the total non-performing loans plus other real estate owned was $7.5 million, or 13.2% of our total loan portfolio.&#160;&#160;Non-performing assets adversely affect net income in various ways.&#160;&#160;While the Company pays interest expense to fund non-performing assets, no interest income is recorded on non-performing loans or other real estate owned, thereby adversely affecting income and returns on assets and equity, while loan administration costs increase and the efficiency ratio is adversely affected.&#160;&#160;When the Company takes collateral in foreclosures and similar proceedings, it is required to mark the collateral to its then-fair market value, which, when compared to the value of the loan, may result in a loss.&#160;&#160;These non-performing loans and other real estate owned also increase the Company&#8217;s risk profile and increase the amount of capital that regulators believe is appropriate for us to achieve and maintain in light of such risks.&#160;&#160;The resolution of non-performing assets requires significant time commitments from management, which can be detrimental to the performance of their other responsibilities.&#160;&#160;There is no assurance that the Company will not experience further increases in non-performing loans in the future, or that non-performing assets will not result in further losses to come.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Commercial and residential real estate markets continue to experience extraordinary challenges following the downturn in recent years.&#160;&#160;Because of the Company&#8217;s substantial reliance on real estate lending, these challenges increase the risk that the Company&#8217;s loans may not be repaid.&#160;&#160;</font>At December&#160;31, 2011 and 2010, approximately 14.2 percent and 15.8 percent of the Bank&#8217;s loans are commercial real estate loans, and 97.2 and 98.3 percent of total loans are real estate loans, respectively.&#160;&#160;Economic factors have caused and may continue to cause deterioration to the value of real estate the Company uses to secure its loans.&#160;&#160;The continued weakness of the economy and the deterioration of our real estate loan portfolio could result in additional increases in the provision for loan losses, higher delinquencies and additional charge-offs in future periods that may materially affect the Company&#8217;s financial condition and results of operations.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">Although the Company makes various types of loans, including commercial, consumer, residential mortgage and construction loans, a significant percentage of the Company&#8217;s loans are commercial loans.&#160;&#160;Commercial lending is more risky than residential lending because loan balances are greater and the borrower&#8217;s ability to repay is dependent on the success of the borrower&#8217;s business.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">Weak economic conditions could continue to have a material effect on the Company&#8217;s financial condition and results of operations.&#160;&#160;Sustained weakness in the real estate market, reduced business activity, high unemployment, instability in the financial markets, less available credit and lack of confidence in the financial sector, among other factors, have adversely affected the Company and the financial services industry in general over the last four years.&#160;&#160;Declines in the housing market over the past four years, with falling prices and increasing foreclosures and unemployment, have negatively impacted the credit performance of real estate-related loans and resulted in significant write-downs of asset values by financial institutions.&#160;&#160;These write-downs have caused many financial institutions to seek</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div><br>
</div>

<div>
<div id="PGBRK" style="TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; WIDTH: 100%; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt">
<div id="FTR">
<div id="GLFTR" style="WIDTH: 100%" align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 8pt">&#160; </font></div>
</div>

<div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always; WIDTH: 100%">
<div style="TEXT-ALIGN: center; WIDTH: 100%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">28</font></div>

<div style="TEXT-ALIGN: center; WIDTH: 100%">
<hr style="COLOR: black" noshade size="2">
</div>
</div>

<div id="HDR">
<div id="GLHDR" style="WIDTH: 100%" align="left"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 8pt"><a href="#TOC">Table of Contents</a></font></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div><br>
</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">additional capital, to reduce or eliminate dividends, to merge with larger and stronger institutions and in some cases, to fail.&#160;&#160;Continuing economic deterioration that affects household and/or corporate incomes could also result in reduced demand for loan or fee-based products and services.&#160;&#160;An increase in the number of delinquencies, bankruptcies or defaults could result in a higher level of nonperforming assets, net charge-offs, provision for loan losses, and valuation adjustments on loans held for sale, which would materially adversely affect the Company&#8217;s financial condition and results of operations.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">The Company&#8217;s financial condition and results of operations could be negatively affected if the Company fails to execute its &#8220;turnaround&#8221; plan.&#160;&#160;</font>The Company has, since its acquisition of the Bank, embarked on a &#8220;turnaround&#8221; plan to cause the Company and the Bank to achieve profitability.&#160;&#160;The success of the &#8220;turnaround&#8221; plan depends on effectively executing management&#8217;s business strategy, which includes plans to continue to grow total assets, the level of deposits and the scale of operations.&#160;&#160;Achieving growth targets requires the Company, in part, to attract customers who currently bank with other financial institutions in the Company&#8217;s markets, thereby increasing the Company&#8217;s share in these markets.&#160;&#160;The Company&#8217;s ability to successfully execute its &#8220;turnaround&#8221; plan will depend on a variety of factors, including its ability to attract and retain experienced bankers, the continued availability of desirable business opportunities, the competitive response from other financial institutions in the market and the Company&#8217;s ability to manage growth effectively.&#160;&#160;There can be no assurance that these opportunities will be available or that the Company will successfully execute the &#8220;turnaround&#8221; plan or business strategy.&#160;&#160;If the Company does not successfully execute the &#8220;turnaround&#8221; plan or business strategy, its business and prospects could be harmed.&#160;&#160;Executing the &#8220;turnaround&#8221; plan includes risks such as:</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div>
<table align="center" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" id="hangingindent" width="100%" style="FONT-FAMILY: times new roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">
<tr valign="top" style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25;">
<td style="WIDTH: 36pt">
<div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">&#160; </font></div>
</td>
<td style="WIDTH: 18pt">
<div style="TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline;" face="Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div>
</td>
<td>
<div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">failure to attract additional capital to support expansion;</font></div>
</td>
</tr></table>
</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div>
<table align="center" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" id="hangingindent" width="100%" style="FONT-FAMILY: times new roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">
<tr valign="top" style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25;">
<td style="WIDTH: 36pt">
<div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">&#160; </font></div>
</td>
<td style="WIDTH: 18pt">
<div style="TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline;" face="Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div>
</td>
<td>
<div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">inability to achieve a level of growth that is translated into profitable operations;</font></div>
</td>
</tr></table>
</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div>
<table align="center" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" id="hangingindent" width="100%" style="FONT-FAMILY: times new roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">
<tr valign="top" style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25;">
<td style="WIDTH: 36pt">
<div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">&#160; </font></div>
</td>
<td style="WIDTH: 18pt">
<div style="TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline;" face="Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div>
</td>
<td>
<div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">failure to adequately address problem credits; and</font></div>
</td>
</tr></table>
</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div>
<table align="center" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" id="hangingindent" width="100%" style="FONT-FAMILY: times new roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">
<tr valign="top" style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25;">
<td style="WIDTH: 36pt">
<div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">&#160; </font></div>
</td>
<td style="WIDTH: 18pt">
<div style="TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline;" face="Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div>
</td>
<td>
<div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">failure to achieve economies of scale and anticipated cost savings.</font></div>
</td>
</tr></table>
</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left">
<div style="TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Additional issuance of common stock may result in dilution to our existing stockholders.</font> <font style="FONT-STYLE: normal"><font style="FONT-WEIGHT: normal">As of March 31, 2012, the Company had $675,425 of its senior convertible notes issued and outstanding, including $565,425 issued and outstanding to Dr. Winston, $340,425 of which will mature in 2012 and $335,000 will mature in 2013.&#160;&#160;As of March 31, 2012, the aggregate amount of the outstanding notes is convertible into 587,871 shares of the Company&#8217;s common stock at maturity based upon the book value of the Company&#8217;s stock <font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-WEIGHT: normal">at 1.5 times the dollar amount of the debt.&#160;&#160;The decision of whether to convert the senior convertible notes into common stock of the Company is at the option of the Company.</font></font></font></font></font></font></div>

<div style="TEXT-ALIGN: left; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt">&#160;</div>

<div style="TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font style="FONT-STYLE: normal; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-WEIGHT: normal">As of March 31, 2012, the Company had 765,427 shares of common stock outstanding.&#160;&#160;The issuance of any such additional shares may result in a reduction of the book value or price of the then outstanding shares of our common stock.&#160;&#160;If we do issue any such additional shares, such issuance also will cause a reduction in the proportionate ownership and voting power of all other stockholders.&#160;&#160;As a result of such dilution, your proportionate ownership interest and voting power will be decreased accordingly.</font></font></font></div>
</div>

<div style="TEXT-ALIGN: left; LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">&#160;</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">The Company is dependent upon the management team.&#160;&#160;</font>The successful operation of the Company will be greatly influenced by its ability to retain the services of existing senior management and to attract and retain additional qualified senior and middle management.&#160;&#160;The unexpected loss of the services of any key management personnel, or the inability to recruit and retain qualified personnel in the future, could have an adverse effect on the Company&#8217;s business and financial results.&#160;&#160;No key-man life insurance policy is maintained on any of our directors, officers or employees.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Unless economic conditions improve, the Company is expected to continue to suffer from credit losses and the Company&#8217;s allowance for loan losses may not be adequate to cover actual losses</font>.&#160;&#160;Credit risk is the risk that loan customers or other counter-parties will be unable to perform their contractual obligations resulting in a negative impact on earnings.&#160;&#160;Like all financial institutions, the Company maintains an allowance for loan losses to provide for loan defaults and non-performance.&#160;&#160;The allowance for loan losses is based on historical loss experience as well as an evaluation of the risks associated with the loan portfolio, including the size and composition of the portfolio, current economic conditions and geographic concentrations within the portfolio.&#160;&#160;If the economy in the Company&#8217;s primary geographic market area, which primarily includes the west-side Chicago neighborhood of North Lawndale, should fail to improve or worsen, this may have an adverse impact on the loan portfolio.&#160;&#160;If for any reason the quality of the loan portfolio should weaken, the allowance for loan losses may not be adequate to cover actual loan losses, and future provisions for loan losses could materially and adversely affect the Company&#8217;s financial results.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div><br>
</div>

<div>
<div id="PGBRK" style="TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; WIDTH: 100%; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt">
<div id="FTR">
<div id="GLFTR" style="WIDTH: 100%" align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 8pt">&#160; </font></div>
</div>

<div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always; WIDTH: 100%">
<div style="TEXT-ALIGN: center; WIDTH: 100%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">29</font></div>

<div style="TEXT-ALIGN: center; WIDTH: 100%">
<hr style="COLOR: black" noshade size="2">
</div>
</div>

<div id="HDR">
<div id="GLHDR" style="WIDTH: 100%" align="left"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 8pt"><a href="#TOC">Table of Contents</a></font></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div><br>
</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">The Company may continue to suffer increased losses in its loan portfolio and in foreclosed assets held for sale despite its underwriting practices</font>.&#160;&#160;The Company seeks to mitigate the risks inherent in its loan portfolio by adhering to specific underwriting practices.&#160;&#160;These practices often include:&#160;&#160;analysis of a borrower&#8217;s credit history, financial statements, tax returns and cash flow projections; valuations of collateral based on reports of independent appraisers; and verification of liquid assets.&#160;&#160;Although the Company believes that its underwriting criteria are, and historically have been, appropriate for the various kinds of loans it makes, the Company has already incurred higher-than-expected levels of losses on loans that have met these criteria, and the Company may continue to experience higher-than-expected losses depending on economic factors and consumer behavior.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">No active trading market exists for the Company&#8217;s common stock.&#160;&#160;</font>There is no public market for the Company&#8217;s common stock, nor is one likely to develop or exist in the immediate future.&#160;&#160;The Company has no present plan to list or qualify its common stock on any securities exchange.&#160;&#160;Therefore, shares of the Company&#8217;s common stock may not be readily marketable in the case of financial emergency or otherwise.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Changes in the domestic interest rate environment could negatively affect the Company&#8217;s net interest income.&#160;&#160;</font>Interest rate risk is the risk that changes in market rates and prices will adversely affect financial condition or results of operations.&#160;&#160;Net interest income is the Company&#8217;s largest source of revenue and is highly dependent on achieving a positive spread between the interest earned on loans and investments and the interest paid on deposits and borrowings.&#160;&#160;The Company&#8217;s net interest spread depends on many factors which are partly or entirely outside of its control, including competition, federal economic, monetary and fiscal policies, and economic conditions generally.&#160;&#160;The Federal Reserve regulates the supply of money and credit in the United States.&#160;&#160;Its policies determine in large part the cost of funds for lending and investing and the return earned on those loans and investments, both of which affect our net interest margin.&#160;&#160;Changes in interest rates affect the Company&#8217;s operating performance and financial condition in diverse ways.&#160;&#160;There are no assurances that the Company&#8217;s efforts to mitigate such risks will be successful.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">The Company faces strong competition.&#160;&#160;</font>The Company faces strong competition for deposits, loans and other financial services from numerous banks, thrifts, credit unions and other financial institutions, as well as other entities that provide financial services.&#160;&#160;The banking business is highly competitive.&#160;&#160;Some of the financial institutions and financial services organizations with which the Company competes are not subject to the same degree of regulation as the Company.&#160;&#160;Most of these competitors have been in business for many years, have established customer bases, are substantially larger, have greater financial and personnel resources, have substantially higher lending limits than the Company and are able to offer certain services, including extensive branch networks, trust services and international banking services, that the Company either does not expect to provide or will not provide for some time, or can offer only through correspondents, if at all.&#160;&#160;Moreover, most of these entities have greater capital resources than the Company has, which, among other things, may allow them to price their services at levels more favorable to the customer and to provide larger credit facilities than the Company.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">The Company is significantly smaller than most of its competitors.&#160;&#160;</font>The Company is one of the smallest financial institutions in the metropolitan Chicago area.&#160;&#160;As such, the Company has a smaller lending limit than other institutions in the market area.&#160;&#160;As of December&#160;31, 2010, the Company&#8217;s legal lending limit was approximately $1.1 million.&#160;&#160;The Company&#8217;s inability to lend larger sums of money may impact its ability to attract larger businesses.&#160;&#160;We intend to accommodate loans in excess of the Company&#8217;s lending limit through the sale of participations in those loans to other banks.&#160;&#160;However, other banks may not be willing to purchase loan participations from the Company, thereby limiting our ability to service customers whose credit needs exceed the lending limit of the Company.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div><br>
</div>

<div>
<div id="PGBRK" style="TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; WIDTH: 100%; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt">
<div id="FTR">
<div id="GLFTR" style="WIDTH: 100%" align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 8pt">&#160; </font></div>
</div>

<div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always; WIDTH: 100%">
<div style="TEXT-ALIGN: center; WIDTH: 100%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">30</font></div>

<div style="TEXT-ALIGN: center; WIDTH: 100%">
<hr style="COLOR: black" noshade size="2">
</div>
</div>

<div id="HDR">
<div id="GLHDR" style="WIDTH: 100%" align="left"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 8pt"><a href="#TOC">Table of Contents</a></font></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div><br>
</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Many of the Company&#8217;s competitors have substantially greater resources to invest in technological improvements.&#160;&#160;</font>The banking industry is undergoing rapid technological changes, with frequent introductions of new technology-driven products and services.&#160;&#160;In addition to providing for better customer service, the effective use of technology increases efficiency and enables financial institutions to reduce costs.&#160;&#160;The Company&#8217;s success depends in part on its ability to address the needs of its customers by using technology to provide products and services that will satisfy customer demands for convenience, as well as to create additional efficiencies in its operations.&#160;&#160;Many of the Company&#8217;s competitors have substantially greater resources to invest in technological improvements.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">The Company may have to pay above-market interest rates to attract depositors and charge below-market interest rates to attract borrowers compared to our competitors in our primary service area.&#160;&#160;</font>Thus far, the Company has been able to pay market interest rates to attract depositors, and has been able to charge market interest rates to attract borrowers in its primary service area.&#160;&#160;However, the banking business is highly competitive, and profitability depends on the ability of the Company to attract depositors and borrowers.&#160;&#160;The Company competes with numerous other lenders and deposit-takers in the area, including other commercial banks, savings and loan associations and credit unions.&#160;&#160;Compared to competitors in the primary service area, the Company may have to pay above-market interest rates to attract depositors and charge below market interest rates to attract borrowers in the future, which may have a material effect on financial condition and results of operations.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">The creditworthiness of other financial institutions could adversely affect the Company.&#160;&#160;</font>The Company&#8217;s ability to engage in routine funding transactions could be adversely affected by the actions and commercial soundness of other financial institutions.&#160;&#160;Financial institutions are interrelated as a result of lending, clearing, counterparty and other relationships.&#160;&#160;As a result, defaults by, or even rumors or questions about, one or more banks, or the banking industry generally, have led to market-wide liquidity problems and could lead to losses or defaults by the Company or by other institutions.&#160;&#160;Many of the transactions engaged in by the Company in the ordinary course of business expose the Company to credit risk in the event of default of our counterparty or customer.&#160;&#160;In such instances, the collateral held by the Company may be insufficient to mitigate losses, as the Company may be unable to realize upon or liquidate at prices sufficient to recover the full amount of the Company&#8217;s exposure.&#160;&#160;Such losses could have a material and adverse effect on results of operations.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">The Company is highly regulated and may be adversely affected by changes in banking laws, regulations and regulatory practices, including the extraordinary actions being taken by the U.S. government in response to the recent financial crises.&#160;&#160;</font>The Company is subject to extensive state and federal legislation, regulation and supervision, including regulation by state and federal banking regulators.&#160;&#160;As a bank holding company, the Company is also subject to regulation by the IDFPR and the Federal Reserve.&#160;&#160;Changes in legislation and regulations may continue to have a significant impact on the banking industry.&#160;&#160;Although some legislative and regulatory changes may benefit the Company, others may increase the costs of doing business and assist competitors which are not subject to similar regulation.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">Changes in laws, regulations and regulatory practices affecting the financial services industry, and the effects of such changes, including the federal government&#8217;s response or lack of response to the ongoing financial crises affecting the banking system and financial markets, are difficult to predict and may have unintended consequences.&#160;&#160;New regulations or changes in the regulatory environment could subject the Company to additional costs, limit the types of financial services and products the Company may offer and/or increase the ability of non-banks to offer competing financial services and products, among other things.&#160;&#160;These changes also can adversely affect borrowers, potentially increasing the risk that they may fail to repay their loans.&#160;&#160;Any failure on the Company&#8217;s part to comply with or adapt to</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div><br>
</div>

<div>
<div id="PGBRK" style="TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; WIDTH: 100%; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt">
<div id="FTR">
<div id="GLFTR" style="WIDTH: 100%" align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 8pt">&#160; </font></div>
</div>

<div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always; WIDTH: 100%">
<div style="TEXT-ALIGN: center; WIDTH: 100%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">31</font></div>

<div style="TEXT-ALIGN: center; WIDTH: 100%">
<hr style="COLOR: black" noshade size="2">
</div>
</div>

<div id="HDR">
<div id="GLHDR" style="WIDTH: 100%" align="left"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 8pt"><a href="#TOC">Table of Contents</a></font></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div><br>
</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">changes in the regulatory environment could have a material adverse effect on its business, financial condition and results of operations.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Higher FDIC deposit insurance premiums and assessments could adversely affect the Company&#8217;s financial condition.</font>&#160;&#160;FDIC insurance premiums increased substantially in 2010, and the Company expects to pay significantly higher FDIC premiums in the future.&#160;&#160;Bank failures have significantly depleted the FDIC&#8217;s Deposit Insurance Fund and reduced the Deposit Insurance Fund&#8217;s ratio of reserves to insured deposits.&#160;&#160;The FDIC adopted a revised risk-based deposit insurance assessment schedule on February&#160;27, 2009, which raised deposit insurance premiums.&#160;&#160;On May&#160;22, 2009, the FDIC also implemented a special assessment equal to five basis points of each insured depository institution&#8217;s assets minus Tier 1 capital as of June&#160;30, 2009, but no more than 10 basis points times the institution&#8217;s assessment base for the second quarter of 2009, which was paid on September&#160;30, 2009.&#160;&#160;Additional special assessments may be imposed by the FDIC for future periods.&#160;&#160;The Company participates in the FDIC&#8217; Temporary Liquidity Guarantee Program (&#8220;TLGP&#8221;), for noninterest-bearing transaction deposit accounts.&#160;&#160;Banks that participate in the TLGP&#8217;s noninterest-bearing transaction account guarantee will pay the FDIC an annual assessment of 10 basis points on the amounts in such accounts above the amounts covered by FDIC deposit insurance.&#160;&#160;To the extent that these TLGP assessments are insufficient to cover any loss or expenses arising from the TLGP, the FDIC is authorized to impose an emergency special assessment on all FDIC-insured depository institutions.&#160;&#160;The FDIC has authority to impose charges for the TLGP upon depository institution holding companies, as well.&#160;&#160;The TLGP was scheduled to end on December&#160;31, 2009, but the FDIC extended it to June&#160;30, 2010 at an increased charge of 15 to 25 basis points, depending on the depository institution&#8217;s risk assessment category rating assigned with respect to regular FDIC assessments if the institution elects to remain in the TLGP.&#160;&#160;These changes have caused the premiums and TLGP assessments charged by the FDIC to increase.&#160;&#160;These actions significantly increased the Company&#8217;s noninterest expense in 2010 and are expected to increase costs for the foreseeable future.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">The banking regulators&#8217; supervisory framework could materially impact the conduct, growth and profitability of operations.&#160;&#160;</font>The Company&#8217;s primary regulatory agencies have broad discretion to impose restrictions and limitations on the Company&#8217;s operations if they determine, among other things, that operations are unsafe or unsound, fail to comply with applicable law or are otherwise inconsistent with laws and regulations or with the supervisory policies of these agencies.&#160;&#160;This supervisory framework could materially impact the conduct, growth and profitability of the Company&#8217;s operations.&#160;&#160;Any failure on the Company&#8217;s part to comply with current laws, regulations, other regulatory requirements or safe and sound banking practices, or any concerns about the Company&#8217;s financial condition, or any related regulatory sanctions or adverse actions against it, could increase costs or restrict the Company&#8217;s ability to operate the business and result in damage to the Company&#8217;s reputation.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="FONT-STYLE: italic; DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">The Company cannot predict the impact of recently enacted legislation, including the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act and its implementing regulations, and actions by the FDIC.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act was signed into law on July&#160;21, 2010.&#160;&#160;This legislation may have an adverse impact on the Company&#8217;s financial results upon full implementation.&#160;&#160;Among other impacts, this legislation establishes a Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, changes the base for deposit insurance assessments, introduces regulatory rate-setting for interchange fees charged to merchants for debit card transactions, and excludes certain instruments currently included in determining the Tier 1 regulatory capital ratio.&#160;&#160;The capital instrument exclusion will be phased-in over a three-year period beginning in 2013.&#160;&#160;Most of the legislation&#8217;s other provisions require rulemaking by various regulatory agencies.&#160;&#160;The Company cannot currently quantify the future impact of this legislation and the related future rulemaking on the Company&#8217;s business, financial condition and results of operation.</font></div>

<div style="LINE-HEIGHT: 1.25; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div>

<div><br>
</div>

<div>
<div id="PGBRK" style="TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; WIDTH: 100%; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt">
<div id="FTR">
<div id="GLFTR" style="WIDTH: 100%" align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 8pt">&#160; </font></div>
